title: 111_s3831
content: The Act may be referred to as the "Postal Operations Sustainment and Transformation Act of 2010" or the "POST Act of 2010." It includes a modified methodology. The Postal Operations Sustainment and Transformation Act of 2010, also known as the POST Act of 2010, amends Section 8348(h) of title 5, United States Code. It requires the Office to redetermine the Postal surplus or supplemental liability annually until September 30, 2042, with results reported to the Postal Service by March 31 of the following fiscal year. Surplus amounts remain in the Fund until distribution is authorized. The Postal Operations Sustainment and Transformation Act of 2010, also known as the POST Act of 2010, requires the Office to establish an amortization schedule for any supplemental liability starting March 31, 2017. The schedule includes annual installments from September 30 of the subsequent fiscal year until September 30, 2042. Amendments to Section 8348(h) of title 5, United States Code, specify the years for redetermining the Postal surplus or supplemental liability and when distribution is authorized. The Postal Operations Sustainment and Transformation Act of 2010, also known as the POST Act of 2010, requires the transfer of any surplus from fiscal years 2010 to 2016 to the Postal Service Retiree Health Benefits Fund, subject to the discretion of the Board of Governors. The transferred amount cannot exceed the specified limit for each fiscal year and will be credited towards the Postal Service's required payments. The POST Act of 2010 mandates the transfer of surplus funds from fiscal years 2010 to 2016 to the Postal Service Retiree Health Benefits Fund, under the Board of Governors' discretion. The transferred amount must not exceed the specified limit for each fiscal year and will be credited towards the Postal Service's required payments. Additionally, any determination related to benefits from civilian employment with the Postal Service must align with section 8339(a). The determination of average pay for individuals under section 8339(a) must align with applicable provisions of law and section 8331(4). This includes considering rates of basic pay during creditable service periods. No separate determination of average pay is allowed for service with the United States Postal Service. The determination of average pay for individuals under section 8339(a) must align with applicable provisions of law and section 8331(4), considering rates of basic pay during creditable service periods. No separate determination of average pay is allowed for service with the United States Postal Service, with the appropriate percentage under section 8339(a) applying to such employment periods. The amendments made by this section apply to the allocation of benefit liabilities between the United States Postal Service and the Treasury of the United States. SEC. 3. OTHER POSTAL SERVICE PROVISIONS. Postal Policy and Specific Powers under title 39, United States Code, are amended to streamline services and redefine postal services to align with the public interest. The Postal Policy and Specific Powers under title 39, United States Code, are amended to streamline services and redefine postal services to align with the public interest. In subsection (d)(2), primary consideration is given to the consistency of closing or consolidation with the government's policy of providing effective postal services to rural areas, communities, and small towns. Subsection (e)(1) is also revised. In subsection (e)(1), the term "nonpostal service" is redefined to exclude services offered under specific authority in title 39 or other statutory authority. Section 411 of title 39, United States Code, is amended to include cooperation with agencies and units of State and local governments. Section 1716(f) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to restrict mailing of nonmailable articles, except as allowed under section 3001(p) of title 39. The mailing of wine or malt beverages by licensed wineries or breweries is allowed under section 3001(p) of title 39, with regulations to be prescribed by the Postal Service. Licensed wineries or breweries can mail wine or malt beverages under specific conditions: the mailing must ensure direct delivery to the addressee or an authorized agent at a postal facility, the recipient must be at least 21 years old and show valid ID upon delivery, the alcohol is not for resale, and the winery/brewery must certify compliance with regulations. Licensed wineries or breweries must provide necessary information for mailing alcohol, including prepayment of state taxes. The amendments made by this subsection will take effect 180 days after enactment. Additionally, arbitration for labor disputes must be resolved within 45 days of appointment. In rendering a decision under this paragraph, the arbitration board shall consider relevant factors such as the financial condition of the Postal Service, the rate system established under the Postal Accountability and Enhancement Act, and pay comparability requirements. Section 3652(a) of title 39, United States Code, is amended to change the reporting deadline. There is no limitation on the frequency of mail delivery. The United States Postal Service has the authority to adjust mail delivery frequency without any limitations. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the date of enactment.
